reviewText:
Early Access Review

Savage is my favorite game of all time. Spent 10k+ hours playing the first game. Imagine my shock and amazement when i became aware of this game 10+ years later!

What this is as of now:

A faithful recreation of my favorite game ever.
Every weapon/unit available
Amazing animations and effects
4+ Awesome UE4 maps and many more to come
Running on a smooth awesome new enigne (ue4)
With some new ideas (and many more to come)

Savage is a game of 2 sides, beasts and humans. Beasts have magic/melee strength. Humans have guns and melee that's also pretty good. The sides are not symmetrical, they are quite different. Humans have block, beasts have leap etc.

This game is based on raw skill, the better player almost always wins. The pacing of savage is somewhat slow, but this isn't a bad thing. It's a relaxing game but at the same time its very intense. The melee is very fast and decisive. You won't last long flailing around.

The same is true of the ranged combat. Better aim, you're going to win. You don't die instantly, the guy who shoots first has almost no advantage even if its a hit. You must land more to actually get a kill, not just surprise someone. The guns are moderately powerful. They aren't crazy. But they're just as important and useful as melee is.

Savage is all about teamwork, timing important things, getting players on the same page. But it's also very much about individual skill. One very skilled player can kill the entire enemy team even with all of them shooting at him! Savage is just pure, raw skill in many situations. Very different from most games nowadays that let lesser skilled players get kills right away.

What I find makes Savage so addicting is that it's all about personal improvement. You can practice dueling and aiming in savage for untold hours and still improve. And the game is paced slow enough to actually see your efforts very clearly. Whether melee or ranged you'll be able to tell right away how much better you've gotten after practicing in the next game or two.

I sincerely hope enough people give this game a chance and realize how deep and rewarding it can be. It's not quite up to it's original glory in terms of content (maps/voices) but it's so far a very good recreation on a new engine. All the guns/units are there. And S2 only plans to improve it in Early Access. We have a bright future ahead of us. Thanks for reading my review!

Early Access Review

I'm going to recommend this game, but I'll do so with caution.

The gameplay is solid and addictive whether you're playing as a unit on the ground (FPS) or manning your team's actions and equipment via the Commander (RTS) role. Two good commanders leading organized teams and having their units work together can lead to a tense match where it's up in the air as to who will win. Resource management and starving enemy resources is a big part of the late game and puts a huge emphasis on maintaining map control.

However, the issue right now is optimisation. I use an FX-8350 and GTX 980, and find that the longer the games go on, the worse the framerate gets. On high/ultra settings the game starts at around 70-80fps, then dips as low as 12 on certain maps. The Eden map is the worst for this, however the snow map seems to be well optimised and I have no problems with it.

So as I say, I can recommend this game but make sure your rig is decent enough that the late-game frame drops aren't going to completely ruin your playing. Hopefully this will be fixed in the near future, at which point I'll recommend with confidence.

Where to start, well i played the original since 2005, and have never stopped playing, even though i tried. Its that adictive.

First the main concept is that its an RTS/FPS Hybrid. You have a Player who is the commander, who plays along the normal RTS gameplay. You build buildings with 10 AI Workers, getting Weapons and improved units for your inventory. the amazing concept is that that Units that normal are AI that you ordwer to atatck are actualy Real life players! you can have up to 11 players playing for you in your team, fighting to destory the other teams base.

The game itself is based around two factions, Beasts and Humans, and the main way to attack is to melee someone. the melee though, is aysmetrical. Humans have Block, Whilst Beasts have leap. However you can also use range. Humans have technology whilst Beasts use Magic.

The Whole game has a high skill ceiling, and i will admit, that it takes time to get good at the game. But the reward is very easy to notice. So lets say you practise for a couple of hours a day. after each day you will notice a slight increase. the different skill levels you can have in this game is so broard and the skill levels of the players are so vast that you will always find someone either lower skilled than you, on the same skill level or higher than you, and its so addictive that you just want to play more to get better and to reach that higher skill level.

In order to win you have to concentrate on teamwork. In Savage, the team that uses teamwork better will 95% always win! whilst it is possible to go it alone and kill lots of people! in order to actualy push the other team back and kill their base, you will need to work together, group up and attack as one team, and this is what makes the game for me so exciting. playing the team work together and fighting side by side with friends.

As a team you push forward accross the map to the other teams base, It is the commanders job to fortify your position by building forward outposts so that you can get to the fight quicker and push your advanatage. its very rewarding to see the enemies base destroyed and very fun too.

Give the game a chance, you will pleasently be surprised. I'm not the only person who has played the original for over 10 years, theres many of us that have because the game is so Unique, Fun, Rewarding, and Skillfull that we keep coming back to play more. Not only that but the DEvelopers are looking to add more to the game for free. mpre maps, different game modes...

It's well worth downloading and playing,

Savage Ressurection   Review:
Overview  Savage Ressurection is an FPS-RTS combo, one seconds you're playing as a commander (RTS), then you switch onto being admist the battlefield (FPS). There's a whole upgrade tree, which takes over an hour to fully unlock and resets every match. It's good fun to try out each and every weapon. The learning curve isn't really that steep, it's just the controls holding me back, from my experience (arrow keys in RTS mode, WASD in FPS mode etc). The maps aren't very large, but oh my do they look amazing on max settings. The foresty maps remind me of Skyrim with an ENB and a few graphic mods, amazing flora, crepuscular rays/god rays looks oh so amazing. Generally a very graphically impressive game, from dynamic shadows to amazing models. A large thumbs up to the devs for this. There's many different playstyles. You can play with bots if you don't have friends to play with. Now, onto the cons. There's an early max of 10 workers, I feel the game could be on a much larger scale with a much higher limit, such as 50, bigger maps and more buildings. It would play a whole different way that way; you have much a larger total base, but so does your enemy (unless they're AI! This game doesn't have AI I would even call easy, but rather harmless, more on AI later), just something I feel would be a nice addition. AI, my team doesn't automatically upgrade themselves to newly unlocked classes, they don't choose new weapons as soon as they're out and have bad pathfinding which takes them around 50 seconds to stop trying doing an impossible task. Maps aren't too impressive in size. There's a need for more larger ones. A matchmaking lobby, I would be nice to be able to fully design what match you want to play: How many people on each team, every bots' difficulty, maps, etc.

I write this review tentatively for now as my final recommendation will depend on a few factors (still I'll get into that).

Ultimately the original Savage was one of the most engrossing and rewarding multiplayer games I've ever had the opportunity to play (and I have over 580 games in this steam account alone). It rewarded skill, was very asymmetrical (yet balanced) and had a fresh mix of RTS/FPS/Action-RPG elements. However, it wasn't perfect and ultimately it's steep learning curve and lack of AI and other features really hampered a multiplayer only game, which didn't fully shine until a map was well populated with 24-48 players (although competitive was 7 v 7 which was perfect due to the incredible skill level).
In this manner the game relied very heavily on the community.

With Savage Resurrection the same elements pretty much apply, although it is releasing into an increasingly crowded and sophisticated marketplace. With the right direction (and atm I've been impressed with 5 updates from developers in the first week), this game could really go places, possibly even becoming a esport. However with empty servers this game is unplayable, which is why I am hesitant to recommend this right now with a limited player base (although if you're in the US or EU you will be all right during peak hours each day).

In short:

+ Amazing potential, fun as it is with most Savage 1 features implemented, could be multiplayer GOTY alongside overwatch and such if done right
+ Developers currently very active and communicating well with the playerbase
+ The steep learning curve rewards skill and makes this game earnestly enjoyable

- Limited player base, which for now is essential to play (AU servers particularly)
- Still missing some savage 1 features however and needs to grow from there
- Gameplay needs to be balanced and modified for new engine (but hey that's what EA is for!)
- Steep learning curve for new player (will help with improved tutorial, AI and community; maybe a commander mentor feature or something for the RTS elements

Early Access Review

Playerbase: There seemed to be about 50 players from Europe and US, adding up to three servers with players - there are of course lots of empty servers! It's a pure multiplayer game so this is a big downside.

Bugs: The game refused to let people respawn. The chat text was barely readable. The error messages, when trying to connect to a server, disappeared so quickly, it was impossible to read them. One character's ability didn't seem to be doing anything, while it is supposed to protect other players from damage.

Teamplay: A good commander is needed to organize the players. He's the one with the best overview. With a bad commander the game is pretty boring and currently most commanders seem to be bad.

Combat: It feels slow and clunky. This isn't anywhere close to games like dark souls or overwatch.

User interface: It's hard to read the chat text. Apparently the tutorial is only an image with some text on it, which I doubt anybody will read.

Graphics: Looks like a 10 years old game. The dota-like creeps that you can farm for gold - which for some unknown reason is limited to 10 k gold pieces - look so terribly bad. There were some pretty rabbits though.

Price: This should be free to play at the moment. You have to buy the game and then there are still micro transactions - eventhough they supposedly aren't planning to make them pay to win. It's definitely not worth the early access price at the moment.

Audio: Nothing special. Didn't notice any good music. The voice acting was good.

Other reviews: Most people who have currently reviewed the game on steam seem to be big fans of the previous games and recommend the new game mostly because they enjoyed the old game.

What do I like about this game?

It's different from the other clone-games. The mix of RTS and FPS could be fun in an organized team.

I wish Steam had a partial recommend option - the game only has EU/US servers currently from the look of things, but would happily recommend game if Oceanic (AUS/NZ) servers become a thing. If you're playing from AUS like I am, expect ~300ms.

The game itself was enjoyable, very reminiscent of the original Savage. Good variety of items/upgrades for each team, with an easy system to inform the commander of your tech progression preferences. Commanding feels more intuitive than previous installations. I found playing the healing classes difficult (mainly shaman, it was hard to understand distance/remain locked to heal someone as everyone is constantly moving/leaping), but am unsure if this was purely a lag issue.

I think something that needs to be looked are enhancing information given to the player - in the loadout screen I'd like to see the statistics of each class (particularly differences in health). Also perhaps a chart describing what the player is rewarded with each time they level up, because it can be easy to forget, or it would be nice to know what's coming next (faster building/more armour etc.)

I was a big fan of the original Savage, and a bigger fan of Savage 2 (also HoN, seeing the predator model in a DotA clone was great). If you liked them, it's essentially more of the same, but better looking and with some changes.
